meta.description:
Label Generation Rules for French

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for French using a limited repertoire as appropriate for a second level domain.

Repertoire

Most references converge on 42 Latin code points.

There is no IDN table published in the IANA Repository of IDN Practices by a .fr ccTLD, but AFNIC has published specificatioons [700] listing the code points accepted for registration as IDNs in the .fr domain.

Excluded code points

Letters documented in some references but not included:

  • U+00DF LATIN SMALL LETTER SHARP S

  • U+00E1 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH ACUTE

  • U+00E3 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH TILDE

  • U+00E4 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00E5 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH RING ABOVE

  • U+00EC LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH GRAVE

  • U+00ED LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH ACUTE

  • U+00F2 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH GRAVE

  • U+00F3 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH ACUTE

  • U+00F5 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH TILDE

  • U+00F6 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00F8 LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH STROKE

  • U+00FA LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH ACUTE

  • U+00FD LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH ACUTE

  • U+0101 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH MACRON

  • U+0113 LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH MACRON

  • U+012B LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH MACRON

  • U+01D4 LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CARON

Extended code points

A number of letters not considered essential to writing the core vocabulary of the language are nevertheless in common use. Where they have not been added to the core repertoire, they are flagged as "extended-cp" in the table of code points. A context rule is provided that by default will prohibit labels with extended code points. To support extended single code points or code point sequences, delete the context "extended-cp" from their repertoire definition.

The sole extended code point is U+0F1 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH TILDE, cited by some references as being used in loan words.

Variants

None.

Character Classes

This LGR defines no named character classes.

Rules

Common rules only:

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in section 4.2.3.1 of RFC5891 [120]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.

  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in section 4.2.3.2 of RFC5891 [120].

Actions

Actions included are the default actions for LGRs as well as those needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks.

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for French for the 2nd Level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, verified in expert reviews by Michael Everson, Nicholas Ostler, and Wil Tan, and based on multiple open public consultations.

References

General references for the language:

  • Atkins, Beryl T. et al. 1987. Robert · Collins dictionnaire français-anglais anglais-français = Collins · Robert French-English English-French dictionary. Paris: Dictionnaires le Robert. ISBN 2-85036-088-0. Glasgow: HarperCollins. ISBN 0-00-433451-5

  • Wikipedia: "French orthography", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_alphabet

  • Omniglot: French (français) http://www.omniglot.com/writing/french.htm

In the listing of the repertoire by code point, references starting from [0] refer to the version of the Unicode Standard in which the corresponding code point was initially encoded. Other references (starting from [100]) document usage of code points. For more details, see the Table of References below.

reference.comment: Code points cited were originally encoded in Unicode Version 1.1

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 6.3.0, (Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2013. ISBN 978-1-936213-08-5) http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.3.0/
Internetstiftelsen i Sverige (IIS), "IDN Reference table for French language" https://github.com/dotse/IDN-ref-tables/blob/master/language-tables/french-lang-ref-table.txt
RFC5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891

reference.comment: This table lists only the characters outside the set a-z

references.reference: ISO/IEC 6937 Third Ed. 2001-12-17- Information technology — Coded graphic character set for text communication — Latin alphabet: Table D.1 (p 35) Use of Latin alphabetic characters.

reference.comment: Code points cited form the standard set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "French" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/french.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from an extended set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "French" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/french.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are rare or archaic

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: "French" http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/french.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the set of Main Letters

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for french [fr] http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/fr.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the Auxiliary set

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for french [fr] http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/fr.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are supported in a national edition of ISO-646.

references.reference: Editions for FR( France) and CA (Canada) of ISO/IEC 646:1991 — Information technology — ISO 7-bit coded character set for information interchange

reference.comment: According to this reference, the alphabet is listed as using the full basic set A-Z
The table only lists code points beyond A-Z
Code points cited are listed as in occasional use for loan words or foreign names

references.reference: Association Française pour le Nommage Internet en Coopération (AFNIC), "IDN technical specifications" http://www.afnic.fr/medias/documents/afnic-idn-technical-specifications.pdf

char.comment: LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH GRAVE
LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CIRCUMFLEX
LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CEDILLA
LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH GRAVE
LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH ACUTE
LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH CIRCUMFLEX
LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH DIAERESIS
LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH CIRCUMFLEX
LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH DIAERESIS
LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH TILDE
LATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH CIRCUMFLEX
LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH GRAVE
LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CIRCUMFLEX
LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH DIAERESIS
LATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH DIAERESIS

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth

rule.name: extended-cp
rule.comment: code points from the extended range

action.comment: by default, labels with leading combining marks are invalid
